awd_titl_txt: Tools for Probing Conformational Dynamics of Membrane Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
Motion in biological molecules, termed dynamics, is a requirement for many biological functions including enzyme catalysis, molecular recognition, protein-protein interactions, and substrate transport. While progress has been made to determine structures of membrane proteins in discrete conformations using X-ray crystallography, much less is known about the role of protein dynamics in function. The overall goal of this project is to develop novel experimental methods to sensitively measure functionally-relevant motions required of membrane proteins. This project will involve high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in research, which will further disseminate knowledge in the interdisciplinary fields of biophysical chemistry, chemical biology, biochemistry, and structural biology and develop STEM workforce for bio-industry and -economy. 

This research will focus on the development and application of oriented sample nuclear magnetic resonance (OS-NMR) experiments. These methods will be applied to three membrane protein transporters of varying size and complexity to establish the feasibility of the methods to reveal functionally important membrane protein dynamics. This project will develop methods to overcome the major challenges in studying membrane protein dynamics. Specifically, biophysical insight into conformational motions of membrane proteins involved in substrate transport and spectroscopic innovation in the development of solid-state NMR techniques to probe dynamics will be developed. to improve undergraduate curricula and scientific training across the 50+ member institutions. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Biological Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The NSF award provided funds for the PI to develop methods for studying membrane protein structure and dynamics and to apply these to proteins involved in molecular transport. During the three-year funding period of the award, the PI published five articles and one book chapter. Among these works was the development of a solid-state NMR method for sensitively assessing protonation states of anionic residues in proteins. The method combines double quantum/single quantum spectroscopy with REDOR dephasing pulses to distinguish aspartate and glutamate residues from overlapping asparagine and glutamine peaks. This approach was used to discern the protonation state of a key residue (Glu14) within the Small Multidrug Resistance (SMR) family. Measurements revealed two independent pKa values for the two Glu14 residues in the asymmetric homodimer of EmrE, which provided key information about the transport cycle. In addition, the PI’s group, in collaboration with a team at the New York University School of Medicine, solved the first structure of NorA, a 388-residue membrane protein efflux pump from S. aureus using cryoelectron microscopy (cryo-EM). Although NorA was too small for cryo-EM by itself (42 kDa), an antibody fragment (50 kDa) bound to NorA increased the effective size large enough for structure determination. Functional assays validated this structure and revealed two anionic residues (Glu222, Asp307) buried inside the membrane that are required for NorA’s function in S. aureus. The findings on two different families of efflux pumps have motivated future experiments including the investigation on mutational consequences on structure, dynamics, and function.

 

Broader Impacts. The NSF grant enabled the PI to pursue student training and establish collaborations to advance laboratory modules in undergraduate and graduate classrooms. One such collaborative effort with faculty at Spelman College and New York University led to a publication in the Journal of Chemical Education which introduced a laboratory module to investigate protein-protein interactions using NMR spectroscopy, teaching students several biochemical techniques along the way. Overall, several high school, undergraduate, and graduate students were offered research opportunities and received training in biochemical and biophysical techniques. All methods developed in this grant have been freely distributed to researchers.

 

The major goals in this project were accomplished.
